abstract: European officials and politicians react angrily to reports that United States has been spying on embassies and diplomatic missions of its European Union allies, saying claims could threaten impending talks with the US on an important trade agreement.

byline.contributor: Stephen Castle reported from London, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Scott Shane contributed reporting from Baltimore.
byline.original: By STEPHEN CASTLE and ERIC SCHMITT

headline.main: Europeans Voice Anger Over Reports of Spying by U.S. on Its Allies
headline.print_headline: Europeans Voice Anger Over Reports of Spying By U.S. on Its Allies

lead_paragraph: European officials said recent reports accusing the United States of monitoring diplomatic offices in New York and Washington could threaten impending talks on a major trade deal.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

snippet: European officials said recent reports accusing the United States of monitoring diplomatic offices in New York and Washington could threaten impending talks on a major trade deal.
